I'll ask the same question as I asked in JIRA here: is there a way to detect this kind of code automatically? It's a good change, but it's better if it's automated.

Oh, thank you for your fast review, @afchung .
Thank you, @tcNickolas . I'll update the code soon.

My favorite question again: is there any way to detect typos systematically, and fix them once for all? Currently we have over a dozen JIRAs which fixed a few typos each, and they all seem to deal with fairly old code, not typos introduced since previous JIRA. The overhead of reviewing and testing each change and then following-up with deleting "deprecated" names (so reviewing and testing another change) seems to be significant.

Today, as I told you, I'm looking at IntelliJ 'Inspect Code' result.
But, it's pretty similar with the previous our discussion. Generally speaking, it's not easy to fix systematically. As you pointed out here, I missed `CommonUtilities.cpp`.

If there is any tool like that, I love to use it. In terms of those kind of fixing, REEF will be the most difficult project because it uses multi-languages. Do you think to make some tools for `REEF`? If someone targets on REEF only, she could make that for REEF definitely.

Hmm, let me try and rephrase. 
Using "Inspect Code" tool shows a lot of other typos in Java code. For example: 
- reef-tang/README.md => delgate, inadvertantly
- org/apache/reef/runtime/common/evaluator/context/ContextManager.java => forecefully
- org/apache/reef/runtime/common/driver/DriverSingletons.java => dure
- org/apache/reef/runtime/common/driver/DriverStatusManager.java => transiton
- org/apache/reef/runtime/common/client/JobSubmissionHelper.java => uniqe etc.

If we aim to have typos-free code, why not go over all such cases once and fix them all at once, rather than picking several at a time? We don't need to create a new REEF-specific tool for this, just use the existing generic one.

I checked the followings.
- Moves API links into `Downloads & APIs` page correctly. 
- Shows ".NET API available since release 0.14.0" properly.
- `change_version.py` changes `Doxygen`, too.

I will merge this.

+1 on fixing typos in a less formal workflow. I think we have two cases to distinguish:
1. Typos in comments and documentation: These can just be done via large pull requests, and the review should be very easy.
2. Typos in APIs, with the two important categories:
   1. Typos in APIs marked `private` or `@Private`: The same as above applies. We can trust each other that a pull request only changing those doesn't change anything else.
   2. Typos in `public` APIs not otherwise marked as internal: Those _should_ go trough a deprecation cycle. But I believe we gave us a free pass for 0.14 for this :-)

Ur. @tcNickolas  and @markusweimer .  I got your points.

By the way, please don't get me wrong. I'm not trying to do typos-free code. 

I think `Real Code` (except comments) is the first citizen. So, this PR is about 'functions and classes' only. Actually, if I have much time, I will fix all of them. I'm doing what I think more important by squeezing my precious time voluntarily.
By the way, @tcNickolas , will you fix those typos you found? Actually, I'm not interested in them .
@jwang98052 Please have a look at this. Thanks!

I did an initial pass. 
A general comment is we need to make all of them injectable, including TaskConfiguration, ContextRuntime and TaskRuntime. 
Also we don't have unit test for those. We should add unit test cases for all of those.
@tcNickolas . It looks good to me, too. I'll test and merge this.

@jwang98052 `TaskRuntime` cannot be injected since `ContextConfiguration` is in the `Driver` project instead of the `Common` project. We will need to deprecate what is in the `Driver` project before we can move on with the rewrite using injection.
This looks good to me, I'll test and merge.
I'll close this first, since we cannot make progress before the `ContextConfiguration` problem is fixed.
@jsjason Could you review this PR?
@bgchun @tcNickolas Yes, I'll take a look.

@anupam128 I agree, it was bothering me as well while I was writing the code. Just to clarify, do you propose just ripping out `IJobResourceUploader.UploadJobResource` and using it as a private function within the client (thus removing the `FileSystemJobResourceUploader` class)? Or perhaps we can directly inject the `FileSystemJobResourceUploader` in the constructor and add a `IArchiveFileGenerator { get; }` in the `FileSystemJobResourceUploader` class such that we don't duplicate code or have to delete `FileSystemJobResourceUploader`?
@jwang98052 could you please have a look when you have time? This will be blocking REEF-1063, REEF-1062, and REEF-1144. Thanks!

`IJobResourceUploader` implementations now deal with already created archive. Archive creation is done only in `YarnREEFDotNetClient`. `IResourceArchiveFileGenerator` remains the same. It is just injected in `YarnREEFDotNetClient` instead of `IJobResourceUploader`. And `IJobResourceUploader` changes as described above.

I had another look. The implementations of contexts on the Evaluator side is a stop-gap until we do the proper rewrite, right?

I think the meta-points in this review are addressed on the dev list. Regarding this work: We should file the JIRAs to remind us to act on the deprecations in the 0.15 cycle. Other than that, it looks good to me.
Thank you for review again. Yep, I made [REEF-1155](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1155) for the deprecations and assigned to me. I will make links among related issues.

@markusweimer yes, this is just a stop-gap such that we support both the new and the old `ContextConfiguration` s in the meantime. The old `ContextConfiguration` is really just a container for `ContextId` at this point though...

The *Bridge classes are annotated as @Private, so, as @markusweimer said, it is possible to rename them directly, without going through deprecation cycle. Can save ourselves some work in REEF-1155 :-)

P.S. I can't merge this PR, as it touches bridge code and thus requires running .NET tests, and my VS issue still blocks me from running full set of tests.

@afchung Sorry for the late response! I've read the code and this is really great! One question: did you check the `count-based aggregation` works correctly? I think it'd be great to have a test case for the `count-based aggregation`. Thanks!

I actually reviewed both and when merge, put a wrong number. Thanks for the catch!

@afchung @yunseong I think having a count-base aggregation test is great. We can perhaps deal with it in another PR.

My main comment is the use of `Clock` to schedule alarms in the data processing path. `Clock` is the main REEF event loop that processes control events. We probably don't want to use it for creating alarms for data processing. Creating a `ScheduledExecutorService` is good.
@markusweimer REEF-1160 has unblocked this. I've addressed the comments and improved the test case, please have another look. Thanks!
